Having chosen this movie based on seeing Jonathan Bennet in "Dogwalker's Christmas Tales" whose sincerity, lovingness and good looks would be a welcome addition to any plot, I was disappointed by the unrealistic holes in the script.  The basic story
(POSSIBLE SPOILERS) is that the wife in this young military family is being deployed in Japan because she speaks Japanese to help after the nuclear disaster and earthquake, leaving behind her husband and 10 year old son.  The first uncomfortable hole was when the little boy was filming her and dad as keepsake until her return.  The son has asked what she loves about her hubby, and, missing an opportunity for a meaningful and compassionate answer as to why people love each other and want to be partners, a frivolous answer about helping with laundry is floated.  Kids can feel in their gut when parents avoid important issues,and are not telling the truth.  Number Two Empty Moment was, when she's been gone a short while, bureaucrats from Child Protective Services show up saying that there is no paperwork proving hubby or anyone else is the little boy's father, a gut wrenching surprise, indeed, as the child is rendered helpless and unaided, even though the person he thought was dad has been there ever since he can remember.  The dad admits meeting mommy when child was still an infant, and marrying her, but failing to go through the formal adoption.  Here, due to subsequent events, ti would have been supportive and realistic to see early life
flashbacks with the three of them both doing a little soldier training possibly, but certainly showing son banging away very musically on his piano when about 3 years old, which is about the earliest when prodigy talent shows up, plus maybe a scene or
two of getting a teacher for some lessons, in order to support the thesis of the story.  But, alas, no.  Nathan, the little boy, overhears daddy's dilemma with CPS, and without one scene of grief or indecision over losing a loving father, stalwartly packs his portable piano, setting off on foot, dressed in military togs to run away, though he knows not where.  His lack of feeling is numbing.  Luckily, he meets a former soldier, also dressed in fatigues, whom we learn is suffering from PTSD, who helps him by
setting up a" meeting" with a rich divorcee and daughter who do eventually take care of him and try to help him by putting him in a local orphanage until his parents can be located.  Scattered are somewhat confusing scenes of him playing his plastic portable piano alternately playing the benefactors' grand piano, sometimes poorly, sometimes brilliantly, without any insight into the inconsistency available for the viewer.  A prodigy doesn't just suddenly become extremely competent without any support, which is the premise the filmmakers seem to be presenting,for, the plot thickens when the orphanage is under threat, the other kids hear
him playing, again poorly, with alternating brilliance, and demand he play at a benefit to save the orphanage.  This is a good development of story, but his lack of experience performing for others (wouldn't mommy and daddy have staged little concerts, if indeed he was so talented?) is a setback which is sluffed off with complements  on his impromptu concert for the kids, resulting in his sudden elevation to star status with orchestra and chorus, and spiffy suit and shiny shoes on performance night.

Meanwhile, daddy is rendered worried and helpless, and  mommy has been reported MIA, while crossing a bridge (whether on foot or in a tank is not revealed) which collapsed , dumping her squadron 100 feet down into the river below.

As no news of her survival or death continues, this is the only time Nathan seems slightly out of balance.  When dad, still worried and helpless, and he are reunited, Nathan says he has lost his psychological/spiritual connection with mom; he can't feel her presence any longer, which takes away his incentive for the concert.  This is another lost moment .  Since military families are often separated (and reunited,too) , some flashbacks to daddy being gone, and mommy soothing son, or mommy being gone and daddy soothing son would have been not only natural and explanatory of the life style, but supportive for this critical moment.  Instead,  Nathan is just left hanging, his hope thin.

So, without spoiling the denouement, there were just too many unsupported steps in this really good story. ( The credits showed
the little star actually wrote some of the music - pretty  cool. Thus the acting seemed improbable and ungrounded by the direction or script, which was just too dissatisfying for me.

A great story about a young boy whose mom is missing in action and the man he thought was his dad is not his birth father, so he can't get custody. The boy, Nathan is temporarily staying in an orphan home which is running out of funds. He is persuaded to give a piano concert to raise funds. He is an amazing pianist. Nathan is played by Ethan Bortnick who really is an amazing talent.  I had never heard of Ethan Bortnick until I saw this movie. Well worth watching.

I haven't been in area in quite awhile and it was nice trying to place where some of the scenes took place.  This is the first movie I have seen with soldiers in or mentioning Detroit where there wasn't an undercurrent of I like you if you visit Detroit I will make sure you are safe, didn't realize the negative messages about Detroit until I moved out of the state.  They did a great job of not putting the city in a bad light and highlighting all of the great people who live there (while still mentioning not everyone who you meet will be a good person).

It was a very enjoyable movie about a young boy whose Mother was in the military and was missing when she went to help during a tsunami in Japan.  The boy ran away because Child Care Services was going to take him away from the man who was taking care of him because he was not his biological father.  When he did go to the shelter, they found out it could not stay open because of lack of funds.  Some young people decided to have a fund raiser and have him play the piano.  He did so well that they were able to raise enough money.  In the end, the Mother returns home.

This is a beautiful story that shows the human nature as it should be ideally. Without appeals to religious believes, the mercy and cooperation among all characters presents a society where human relations lead lead to to a satisfactory solution of an unexpected situation. Even the military is presented doing its duty not in conflict but in international cooperation. Human society as we desire it to be for the best for humankind.

Entertaining but simplistic.  I enjoyed the story and likable characters but kept wanting more answers to difficult questions.  Why couldn't the state qualify the step-father as a guardian or foster parent? Why the orphanage and not a group home? why a rich little girl is so confident, directive of others, and able to get adults to listen to her? How do the characters avoid being just 2 dimensional cut outs being positioned for scenes without more time to group or grapple with issues?

This little boy's mom goes to Japan to help with a earth quake and titlewave and goes MIA. While they are looking for her he finds out his dad is not his birth father and as paperwork hasn't been filled out the government comes to take the boy. So the boy runs away. It seems no matter where the boy goes he touches lives and draws out the best in others. His music is only the smallest part of this and when he decides to be found he is sent to an orphanage  on the verge of closer. So the kids plan a concert starring the runaway boy without telling anyone. Any more and I'll give away the whole film but even if you know what happens it's worth the watch.

I have seen Ethan Bortnick perform live several times.  That boy is a true prodigy.  It's unfortunate this schmaltzy film was used to display his unique talent.  The story is terrible and plays on every possible tragedy (deployment, loss of a parent, paternity, foster care, homelessness, etc).  It all gets neatly tied up at the end, too neatly.  The only saving grace is watching and listening to Ethan play.  Plan to fast forward to those parts.  Having a son deployed I know that after a family is told someone is assumed dead, they don't just dropped them off at the house later when they are found to greet the family at the front door.

The acting is sweet and the ending is endearing. The story is charming, a bit sad and uplifting.  The music/songs are incredible! I will watch it again. The talent of this young man, Ethan 10 at this time, is extraordinary! I didn't suspect until the near end that he may be singing the songs. But, surely he couldn't be playing the piano so eloquently with such small fingers. Upon reading the credits - sure enough, he did sing, play the piano, write and produce this film. According to Ethan's online biography, he has made over $40 million for charity. He is one gifted guy.
Gave up early just did not seem true enough even for fiction.

Being that I am a vietnam veteran, a Iranian hostage veteran, and a piano player, I am astounded! Whether or not the young man is actually performing the actual performance is trivial. This movie will make you cry like a little kid and move your heart to places that it has always longed to be. Thank you young Mr. Bortnick for reminding me that, ANYTHING IS POSSIBLE! Hope to hear more of you in future.

Excellent family movie - all to the imagination of a young child.  Unrealistic and disturbing that the child's custody was being taken away from the father that raised him and the only father he knew.  That might send a wrong message specially since his mother was MIA on a military mission and the mother had left custody of her child with her husband.  Being from a military family and being raised during the Vietnam War were my father served 2 terms no one really knows the stress and anxiety these children go through knowing that our father could be killed any day.  It is a horrible thing for any child to have to live through. This movie had a happy ending thankfully.

I loved every single minute of this movie.  Everyone should see it to see what the love of a family can make happen.  I wish I could put into words how it made me feel.  I loved what the little girl said, "Anyone can be a Father, but not everyone could be a Dad."  Life can change in an instant.  Always tell the people you love how much you love them because at the end of the day they could not be there, God could want them back.  God worked a miracle in the life of this little boy.  He is amazing.  This movie had some of the most incredible actors in it I have ever seen.  You have to see this movie to believe it.  Thank You God for letting them make such an inspirational movie.  If I could give it more than 5 stars I would.
I wasn't sure about this movie at the beginning, it started out a little boring. However farther into the movie it held your attention and had a good plot. I would recommend this movie!

This is a great family movie but one that adults can learn a lot from the children.  While not specifically a Christian film, scriptural principles are the basis of this movie.  Jesus said to His disciples that we needed to become like children in order to enter the kingdom of heaven.  Why?  Children have not yet been tainted by the world and instinctively believe that anything is possible.  This young man is remarkable and his willingness to move beyond his fears to help others, even while he is in the midst of his own pain and situation, will bring you to tears!  There is specifically one scene in the movie where the innocence of a child is so clearly demonstrated when the young man is hiding in the basement and asks where he can sleep.  You need to be alert to not miss it, but I  found it to be priceless.  This is a movie that I'll be adding to my movie collection.
It was a very good movie in that with the true love between mother and child anything is possible. Very emotionally balanced with up and down surprises that make it what it is Sandra.

This was a good movie. No bad words.

Ethan is extremely talented and has been since a very early age.  We just saw him at around 5 years old playing a ragtime piano piece with extreme proficiency on the Leno show.  We really enjoy his personality and his music ability.  He is like a grownup in a boy's body!
there was nothing to profound about this.  the plot was thin. one did acquainted with ethan and his abilities with music.i looked him up on you-tube. very impressive.

This was one of the sweetest movies I've seen in some time. Keeping Faith,Hope & Love active moves the hand of God. When

Ethan Bortnick is a gift to our planet, especially children and music-lovers. This is a sweet and inspiring story which beautifully show-cases Ethan's gifts as well as societal concerns worthy of our loving support. Anything Is Possible emanates wisdom and hope of value to all ages.

As Einstein said, "There are two ways to live your life. One is as though nothing is a miracle. The other is as though everything is a miracle." Ethan, I'm with you. Anything is possible!

With a deep bow of gratitude and respect,
~ Jeanine DuBois, Compassion's Doorway

It was a beautiful movie that I really enjoyed watching. I ordered the DVD but couldn't wait until it came so I rented it on Amazon after watching Pastor Marvin Miles on TBN talking about it and showing the trailer. I couldn't hold back the tears it was really touching. I am proud of all the cast, IGC and for Pastor Marvin Miles for having the vision to let God move thru him to produce this movie. If you haven't seen it yet, you need to watch it. It will definitely lift your spirit and make you believe that Anything Is Possible.

I want to give this movie more stars for the sweet message and family-friendly viewing but the acting was so sad. The piano prodigy has a great voice and he plays beautifully but his acting was very awkward and all the dialogue was amateurish. I also didn't like that a piano prodigy goes from barely knowing the notes to playing amazingly concert-style with original music in about a week. 3 Stars for effort but it really missed the mark for me.
I do have to say that Captain Miles was my favorite and the best actor in this film.

The script is a little hard to believe, but otherwise a good movie. Loved the way the movie actually showed identifiable scenes from Detroit, and the actors were as diverse as Detroit. Heartwarming to see a movie that shows people being kind to each other!!
This is a wonderful movie. It brought me to tears of happiness and sadness.

Ethan Bortnick (Nathan) is a delight...no, really. And in real life, he is a prodigious young entertainer. I won't spoil it all by recalling all of the "child prodigies" who were exploited beyond their emotional and intellectual ability to handle all the nonsense of showbiz, but if this is what he wants to do, God help him! The movie is way too saccharine for my sensibilities, but the kids in your family, will love it. I love Jonathan Bennett, he's hot and gives a very sincere performance here along with another favorite, Lacey Chabert (she fully gets the child star biz of show biz). The script is pure cornball, adult members of the cast are stiff as cardboard and the kids (in angel mode), are...well, kids. Deetroit shines and the diversity of the cast as well as shoutouts to troops (those serving abroad and those suffering at home), are duly noted, if a bit overwrought. The closing scenes--the concert with Bortnick in full glory, got me. This was not the diversion I wanted, but guess I needed a little boost.
Nice family story.  Totally unrealistic but fun.

It was alright. Not good. Not bad. Just, alright. The script is weak and contrived and the acting is a mixed bag. There are some talented actors in it but the dialogue doesn't give much room for their talents. In many places, it is just unrealistic. The talent of the young boy is quite impressive though. The film will pull at your heartstrings. I found myself crying at the end but I wasn't really invested in the movie. It was just too corny and contrived.
Wow. For a low budget film with only a couple seasoned actors, that was a really enjoyable film. Inspiring and touching and kind of magical by the end. Movie with a heart.
Was just an ok movie.
